messageBody:
[Read_Alphabet] Finally a reply
I had been meaning to reply to your questions for some time.


1) How do each of you use the Read Alphabet personally?

First, when I'm doing creative writing (in this case, playwriting).  Though it may sound strange, I do it to slow me down in the writing process.  Instead of mad orthodox scribbling, the calligraphic qualities of QS help me to relax, think about what I'm doing, and  enjoy the process of putting ideas to paper. Speed will come someday, I hope, but meanwhile patience is a great teacher.  Days later, when I am transcribing the QS into orthodox on the computer, I get my most valuable QS experience -   reading your own writing.

Second, in my job I am always interviewing potential clients.  I used to make little notes to myself on their applications, just to help me remember them days or weeks later.  These were usually embarrassing comments, actually, but the more embarassing they were, the easier it was to remember them. So now I can write <bAYB az a biljRB bYl> or <simplI tM mac mEkap!> without fear of the client or anyone else knowing what I wrote.

If you've ever tried calligraphy, you will now that it's harder to learn how to change the way you write an "a" for example, than it is to learn for the first time, as a thinking adult, how to make a "A" and then make it connect to a "Y" or a "n"

Just for practice, I also do my grocery list in QS.


2) Is there a dictionary of any sort for spellings in the Read
Alphabet?  How do you know if you're spelling words right?  I've
noticed some misspellings in posts, and I wonder about that.

You hit a sore point here in the QS community, and  even more so in the Shavian community, which seems more hung up on "correctness" than we are at the Read site.

To write an "orthodox" dictionary, somebody looked at how the majority of educated people spelled a word ("the Authorities") and then they also recorded how it sounded in fancy and mind-boggling notation, which varied from dictionary to dictionary.  A QS dictionary, on the other hand, has only to decide how "Authorities" pronounce  words, and transcribe the words accordingly.  (Think of My Fair Lady, and Rex Harrison copying down the patois of the Cockneys.)  So the question remains, "Which authoritative accent will the QS dictionary accept?"  The Read community has wisely been been loath to try to set up any accent as more acceptable than another.

All this being said, I have been keeping my own dictionary for over a year now, and it is a great way to double check myself, and to bring consistency at least within my own practice.  I have recently begun transcribing the Preface to Androcles and the Lion (the play having already been accomplished by better ears than mine.)  After the first 4500 words, (alas, only 20% of the whole) I put the text into a database file to discover how many different spellings I had used for the same English word.  It was frightening how all-over-the-place my spelling was.

Before proceeding with the work, I have stopped to reconcile all these different spellings - quite a project in itself. So what I am building is a dictionary of how I write - nothing authoritative, but, in its own way, at least consistent within itself.

Yet I realize that the only fruits of all these labors will be a record of how a middle-aged American, born in  Alabama, raised in Missouri, and trying to affect an East Coast accent, would sound.

Also,
what about punctuation?  Wouldn't one think that punctuation that
would connect to the letters would fit better, as well as numbers
that connect?

I don't see that as much of a saving.  Most Shavians, in honor of Shaw, I suppose, already eliminate apostrophes all together. What's left?  Quotes are now one mark (<) rather than two (").  That's  nice. What could be more efficient than "."?  How many times do we use question marks anyway?

As for numerals, you would just be throwing out a perfect shorthand to install another one.  The whole point of QS or Shavian, is a one-to-one correspondence between sound and symbol.  What could be more efficient than 12345 etc?  Just be thankful we aren't using Roman numerals.








Please reply this time, thank you.
